results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis docks with International Space Station; Edward Lu, American astronaut, and Russian counterpart Yuri Malenchenko take spacewalk to lay cable and erect boom for compass; photo (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Shuttle Docks at Station; Long Spacewalk Begins

results.snippet: Ending a two-day chase, the space shuttle Atlantis sped alongside the International Space Station early Sunday and latched on.    Early this morning, Edward Lu, an American astronaut, and Yuri Malenchenko, a Russian cosmonaut, floated out of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Ending a two-day chase, the space shuttle Atlantis sped alongside the International Space Station early Sunday and latched on. Early this morning, Edward Lu, an American astronaut, and Yuri Malenchenko, a Russian cosmonaut, floated out of the shuttle for a 110-foot walk outside of the station.

results.abstract: Dr Edward Lu and Col Yuri Malenchenko leave space shuttle Atlantis and make grueling climb up International Space Station to lay cable and install boom for navigation unit on station's exterior; walk, 110 feet from Atlantis's cargo bay, is farthest distance any NASA spacewalker has ventured while tethered; photo (M)
results.snippet: An American astronaut and a Russian cosmonaut drifted out of the space shuttle Atlantis early today, making a successful climb up the International Space Station that was more spacehike than spacewalk.    Dr. Edward Lu and Col. Yuri Malenchenko made...
results.lead_paragraph: An American astronaut and a Russian cosmonaut drifted out of the space shuttle Atlantis early today, making a successful climb up the International Space Station that was more spacehike than spacewalk. Dr. Edward Lu and Col. Yuri Malenchenko made the grueling ascent to lay cable and install a boom for a navigation unit on the exterior of the 140-foot station during their 6-hour, 14-minute spacewalk. They carried the bundled cables on their backs, along with the boom and their tools.

results.abstract: Gen Gherman Stepanovich Titov, fighter pilot who in 1961 became second Russian to fly in space and first man to sleep there, dies at 65; photo (M)

headline.main: Gherman Titov, 65, Second In Quest to Be First in Space

results.snippet: Gen. Gherman Stepanovich Titov, a fighter pilot who in 1961 became the second Russian to fly in space and the first man to sleep there, died on Wednesday while taking a sauna in his apartment here, officials said today.    He turned 65 on Sept. 10....
results.lead_paragraph: Gen. Gherman Stepanovich Titov, a fighter pilot who in 1961 became the second Russian to fly in space and the first man to sleep there, died on Wednesday while taking a sauna in his apartment here, officials said today. He turned 65 on Sept. 10. Initial reports said he died of carbon-monoxide poisoning.

results.abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews books The Bottoms by Joe R Lansdale, The Sugar House by Laura Lippman, Blood-Red Rivers by Jean-Chrisophe Grange, translated by Ian Monk, Fall of a Cosmonaut by Stuart M Kaminsky and Beacon Street Mourning by Dianne Day; drawing (M)
results.snippet: When times are hard, people tell stories. Heads huddled on the sleeping porch, at the barber shop, around the kitchen table, they spin tall tales about the panther that chased a woman and her baby in a buckboard, the tornado that swept up Old Man...
results.lead_paragraph: When times are hard, people tell stories. Heads huddled on the sleeping porch, at the barber shop, around the kitchen table, they spin tall tales about the panther that chased a woman and her baby in a buckboard, the tornado that swept up Old Man Chandler in his outhouse, the Goat Man who snatches children who try to cross the Swinging Bridge -- wondrous yarns like the ones in THE BOTTOMS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $24.95), a pungent period mystery by Joe R. Lansdale that draws on the idiom of regional folk legend to filter the horror of race violence and serial murder in a small East Texas town during the Depression. The aged narrator, Harry Collins, is lying in a rest home and letting his mind drift back to the events that changed his life in 1933. Picking up the story in his own voice, the 11-year-old Harry shares his innocent wonder at the wild woods, his childish openness to neighbors black and white, and his terror when he and his little sister find the mangled body of a black prostitute in the deep bottom lands along the Sabine River. Harry's father, the town barber and constable, does his best; but when the killer claims a white victim, he can't stop his Klan neighbors from lynching an old black man for the crimes. In this tale of dark enchantment, it falls to Harry to find the truth behind the legend, to look beneath the skin to learn the secret ways of grown-ups -- and to share his bitter lessons with us all.
